data.title: Lady ‚ÄòMaster‚Äô Yang Jiang Passes Away at 105
data.meta_description: China's beloved writer Yang Jiang has passed away at the age of 105. As Chinese netizens collectively express their condolences, 'Master' Yang Jiang has become a trending topic on Sina Weibo.
data.text:
PREMIUM NEWSLETTER | ISSUE #35

This week‚Äôs newsletter:

‚óºÔ∏é 1. Editor‚Äôs Note ‚Äì Going the wrong way

‚óºÔ∏é 2. What‚Äôs New and Noteworthy ‚Äì A closer look at featured stories

‚óºÔ∏é 3. What‚Äôs Trending ‚Äì Hot highlights

‚óºÔ∏é 4. What‚Äôs Noteworthy ‚Äì Young woman‚Äôs lonely death in rented apartment

‚óºÔ∏é 6. What‚Äôs Popular ‚Äì Fan Zhendong‚Äôs pluche toys

‚óºÔ∏é 7. What‚Äôs Memorable ‚Äì Ren Zhiqiang‚Äôs Weibo exit

‚óºÔ∏é 8. Weibo Word of the Week ‚Äì Fandom-ization

Dear Reader,

‚ÄúApology! Apology!‚Äù Dozens of delivery drivers chanted, standing together in front of Hangzhou‚Äôs Xixi Century Square. The group of workers, mostly men, had gathered in front of the complex after learning about an incident that took place just hours earlier.

One of their colleagues, a young delivery driver for the Meituan platform named Wang, had accidentally damaged a fence while trying to enter the complex to deliver a food order on August 12. The security guard stopped him and allegedly demanded 200 yuan ($28) in compensation. Onlookers captured a video showing Wang kneeling before the guard, pleading for leniency. He could not afford the fee nor the kerfuffle‚Äîit was peak lunch hour, and he needed to deliver his order on time.

The incident immediately went viral in WeChat groups. The image of the delivery driver on his knees, hands in his lap, helplessly looking up at the security guard, resonated with many delivery workers, sparking anger. Members of the delivery community decided to gather at the scene and protest the way their colleague had been treated.

As more delivery drivers arrived, tensions escalated (video). At least twenty police officers, including a specialized police unit, were called in to deescalate the situation, and the security guard was rushed away for his own safety.

That same night, local authorities issued a notification about the incident, urging people to remain calm and show more tolerance and understanding during these blazing hot summer days.

But the simmering tension beneath the surface runs deeper than just the summer heat.

In recent years, many viral videos have captured the hardships faced by Chinese food delivery workers, who endure scorching heat, heavy rain, and thunderstorms to deliver their orders. On August 21, a delivery driver in Pingyang collapsed while picking up a food order at a restaurant but insisted on completing the delivery (he was eventually taken to the hospital by ambulance). Other videos on platforms like Douyin show delivery riders breaking down during work.

The pressure they face is real, and the work they do is intense. China‚Äôs main food delivery platforms, Meituan and Ele.me, backed by tech giants Tencent and Alibaba, employ a combined 10 million delivery drivers. Their daily work is monitored by algorithmic management tools. The workload is high, the overwork is severe, the income is low, and the conditions are often unsafe.

Most of these workers are lower-educated migrant workers from rural areas who were already in vulnerable positions before taking these jobs. They face challenges such as limited job opportunities, inadequate medical care, poor nutrition, and sometimes language barriers or social alienation in China‚Äôs urban jungle. The digital control makes their work stressful‚Äîa late order or bad review can cost them income, and the algorithm doesn‚Äôt account for challenges like high staircases or busy roads.

Recent studies show that these factors make China‚Äôs food delivery drivers highly susceptible to anxiety and depression. One study focusing on urban delivery drivers in Shanghai found that 46% of the drivers surveyed reported anxiety symptoms, and 18% experienced depression.

While the recent Hangzhou incident and other viral moments have drawn attention to the stressful working conditions and weak social status of China‚Äôs food delivery workers, a new Chinese movie presents a different perspective on the ‚ÄúWaimai brothers‚Äù (Â§ñÂçñÂ∞èÂì•, w√†im√†i meaning takeout or delivery).

Upstream ‚ÄúÈÄÜË°å‰∫∫Áîü‚Äù (N√¨x√≠ng R√©nshƒìng),a movie by director and star actor Xu Zheng (ÂæêÂ≥•), was released on August 9. The story revolves around former programmer Gao Zhilei‚Äîplayed by Xu himself‚Äîwho loses his job and savings. To support his family and ill father, he enters the gig economy as a delivery worker.

The Chinese title of the movie, ÈÄÜË°å‰∫∫Áîü, translates to ‚Äúa life against the current.‚Äù The term ÈÄÜË°å (n√¨x√≠ng) literally means ‚Äòto go the wrong way‚Äô or ‚Äòto move in the opposite direction,‚Äô and it has been translated as ‚Äòupstream‚Äô in this case. Since early 2020, Chinese state media have used the term ÈÄÜË°åËÄÖ n√¨x√≠ngzhƒõ, ‚Äúthose going against the tide‚Äù to refer to frontline workers and everyday heroes who made significant contributions or sacrifices for society, particularly during the pandemic or in emergencies such as forest fires.

Although Upstream does highlight some of the challenges faced by Chinese gig workers, it is largely a feel-good movie that avoids a deeper exploration of the marginalized status and precarious work conditions of gig workers. The title and story align with the narrative promoted by official media about China‚Äôs food delivery workers, especially during the pandemic when their work was extra demanding: instead of lobbying for better labor conditions, they were praised as heroic and altruistic, noble national heroes who act for the greater good. As one driver quoted in a study by Hui Huang put it: ‚ÄúThey treat us as heroes in the media, but as slaves in reality.‚Äù

This sentiment also plays a role in the public‚Äôs reception of Upstream, as discussed in a recent article by Sixth Tone. Many feel that the film exploits the struggles of China‚Äôs gig workers for entertainment and profit rather than genuinely advocating for their rights and well-being. Turning such precarious and often harsh realities into a feel-good narrative is seen by some as ‚Äúthe wrong way‚Äù rather than ‚Äúupstream.‚Äù Some have even described it as ‚Äúrich people acting poor and making the poor pay for it.‚Äù

One Zhihu user placed the actual film poster next to an alternative version featuring delivery driver Wang in a vulnerable, knee-down position, which powerfully symbolizes how many delivery drivers perceive their precarious status in society.

There is, however, an upside to the heightened attention on China‚Äôs food delivery workers and the increased awareness of the challenges they face regarding working conditions, income instability, and social status. For instance, the absurdity of having to rely on algorithms for work is now raising discussions. Delivery algorithms put pressure on riders by determining their tasks based on factors like proximity to the restaurant, location, and delivery history. These algorithms calculate precise delivery times based on ideal conditions, leaving little room for traffic delays, extreme weather, or restaurant preparation times. Riders can get caught in ‚Äúalgorithm traps‚Äù (ÁÆóÊ≥ïÈô∑Èò±) because the faster they work, the stricter the algorithm tightens delivery windows, and they may face penalties or reduced earnings if they fail to meet the expected times.

The fact that, through Upstream and the Hangzhou incident, people are now acknowledging the pressure that Meituan and Ele.me drivers face under such digital systems is already a big improvement from 2019, when debates centered on whether or not you should say ‚Äúthank you‚Äù to acknowledge the service provided by delivery drivers.

‚ÄúMaybe some parts of this film don‚Äôt fully connect with reality,‚Äù author Yan Lingyang (ÊôèÂáåÁæä) wrote on Weibo about Upstream: ‚ÄúBut under the current system, I think it‚Äôs already quite daring. It reflects various issues such as the economic downturn, housing bubbles, corporate burnout [involution], low wages for grassroots workers, lack of rights protection, and algorithm traps.‚Äù

Chinese blogger Cui Zijian (Â¥îÁ¥´Ââë) recently also spoke out against the exploitation of drivers by platform companies, arguing that algorithms should be improved and suggesting that delivery riders be included in unions. While the reception of Upstream and the Hangzhou delivery driver protest might seem to indicate that things are going the wrong way, the increased awareness actually points in the right direction‚Äîtoward greater understanding of the precarious situation faced by millions of workers.

I‚Äôd love to dive deeper into topics such as these that are so relevant in everyday society and show how digital platforms impact the lives of people. Since I‚Äôm always reporting the latest trends, this often leaves little room for the more insightful articles I love to write for you. I‚Äôve therefore decided that I will focus on more deep-dives and less short trends on What‚Äôs on Weibo in the nearby future ‚Äì I will still give you timely updates on the latest trends via the Weibo Watch newsletter. I‚Äôm brainstorming on how to go about this, and I will take you along in how I plan to do this and keep deliving the content you like. It can be challenging to divide time between daily trends and deeper dives but I can‚Äôt complain ‚Äì thankfully, there‚Äôs no algorithms chasing me.

In the near future, I‚Äôd love to dive deeper into topics like these, which are so relevant in China‚Äôs everyday society and show how platform culture, social media and digitalization impact people‚Äôs lives and livelihood. Since I‚Äôm always covering the latest trends, it often leaves little time for the more in-depth articles about the issues behind China‚Äôs hot topics and tech developments. Because of this, I‚Äôve decided to gradually shift my focus toward deeper dives instead of shorter trend articles for What‚Äôs on Weibo. I‚Äôll still provide timely updates on the latest trends through the Weibo Watch newsletter. I‚Äôm currently brainstorming how to make this transition, and I‚Äôll keep you involved as I work on continuing to deliver the content you enjoy. Finding the right balance between covering trends and producing in-depth articles can be challenging, but I can‚Äôt complain‚Äîthankfully, no algorithms are chasing me.

Miranda Barnes has contributed to the compilation and interpretation of the topics featured in this week‚Äôs newsletter. Ruixin Zhang has authored the insightful fan culture article, and contributed to the word of the week. As always, if you have any observations or ideas you‚Äôd like to share, please don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out to me.

Best,

Manya Koetse

(@manyapan)

The initial story that went viral in WeChat groups (links of screenshots) claimed that the delivery driver was a woman, and that the security guard had forced her to kneel. This detail intensified the outrage. However, it was later revealed that the driver was actually a thin, male worker who knelt voluntarily, in hopes of speeding up the process.

What‚Äôs Trending

A recap of hot highlights and online discussions

üêí Black Myth Wukong

A Chinese game that has been in development for over four years is top trending on Weibo this week. Black Myth: Wukong (ÈªëÁ•ûËØùÊÇüÁ©∫) was officially released on August 20, surpassing all expectations. Within an hour of its release, it topped the ‚ÄúMost Played‚Äù list on Steam, with over 2 million concurrent players.

Developed by Game Science, a startup founded by former Tencent employees, Black Myth: Wukong draws inspiration from the classic Chinese novel Journey to the West. This epic tale, filled with heroes and demons, follows the supernatural monkey Sun Wukong as he accompanies the Tang dynasty monk Xuanzang on a pilgrimage to India to obtain Buddhist s≈´tras (holy scriptures). The game focuses on Sun Wukong‚Äôs story after this journey. Black Myth: Wukong has been such a massive success that anything associated with it is also going viral‚Äîa merchandise collaboration with Luckin Coffee sold out instantly.

ü•á Olympic Heroes Hailed at Home

China‚Äôs Olympic champions, including Quan Hongchan (ÂÖ®Á∫¢Â©µ), who we also discussed in our last newsletter, have received warm welcomes home as their hometowns were transformed into temporary pilgrimage sites, complete with medal ceremonies and huge posters. There have been many touching moments during the champions‚Äô return. For example, Boxing Gold medalist Wu Yu jumped into her mom‚Äôs arms and cried like a little kid after returning from her Paris adventure.

In addition to the warm receptions in their hometowns, the champions were also honored in Beijing at the Great Hall of the People, where Xi Jinping met with the athletes on August 20 and praised them for their performance and sportsmanship throughout the Paris Games. A related hashtag has garnered 360 million views on Weibo ( #‰∏≠ÂõΩ‰ΩìËÇ≤‰ª£Ë°®Âõ¢ÊÄªÁªìÂ§ß‰ºö‰∏æË°å#)

üö® Magic Carpet Ride Gone Wrong

The ‚Äúmagic carpet ride‚Äù at the popular Detian Waterfall scenic area in Guangxi‚Äôs Chongzuo drew significant attention on social media earlier this month after a malfunction led to tragic consequences. This attraction, designed to transport visitors up the mountain as they sit backward on a moving belt, suddenly malfunctioned on August 10, causing passengers to slide uncontrollably downwards (here you can see how the attraction normally operates).

The accident resulted in one tourist‚Äôs death and injuries to 60 others. A joint investigation team was established to determine the cause of the incident. Preliminary findings suggest that a steel buckle at the belt‚Äôs joint broke, causing the belt to rapidly slide downward. With passengers spaced about a meter apart on the conveyor belt, the sudden movement led to collisions, with some individuals being crushed, particularly at the lower end. Those responsible for the attraction‚Äôs operation and maintenance have been detained in accordance with the law for their roles in the incident, which will be further investigated.

üçµ Eileen Gu Controversy

Whether it‚Äôs her athletic career or personal life, Eileen Gu (Ë∞∑Áà±Âáå) always seems to find herself trending in China. The American-born freestyle skier and gold medalist who represented China at the 2022 Beijing Olympics sparked discussions during the Paris Olympics due to her connection with L√©on Marchand, the renowned French Olympic swimmer. Marchand faced significant backlash on Chinese social media after being accused of ignoring a handshake from Team China‚Äôs coach Zhu Zhigen (Êú±ÂøóÊ†π) (#È©¨Â∞îÂ∞öÊó†ËßÜÊ±™È°∫ÊïôÁªÉÊè°Êâã#). A brief video of the incident went viral, showing the Chinese coach approaching Marchand to congratulate him, only for Marchand to seemingly ignore him and walk away.

Amid the controversy, netizens noticed that Gu, who had previously interacted with Marchand online, deleted her comments on his Instagram, including a compliment on his latest Olympic victory (‚Äúincredible‚Äù) (#Ë∞∑Áà±ÂáåÂà†‰∫ÜÁªôÈ©¨Â∞îÂ∞öÁöÑÊâÄÊúâinsËØÑËÆ∫#). However, when videos surfaced of Gu dancing closely with Marchand, she was accused of being two-faced or insincere. While some initially saw her deletion of the interactions as a patriotic gesture, many now believe she was simply being opportunistic.

But Gu is clapping back at her haters, suggesting that she can never please everyone. When someone called her out for being ‚Äúa traitor‚Äù to her country, Gu reportedly replied, ‚ÄúWhich one?‚Äù The issue of Gu‚Äôs nationality has been a somewhat sensitive topic since she first represented China, with many questioning whether she holds a Chinese or American passport (as China does not recognize dual nationality). Gu‚Äôs previous statement, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm American when in the US and Chinese when in China,‚Äù has also triggered dissatisfaction among Chinese audiences. On Instagram, she has now confronted her haters: ‚ÄúIn the past five years, I‚Äôve won 39 medals representing China and spoken out for China and women on the world stage. What have the haters done for the country?‚Äù

üíç New Marriage Rules

A revised draft regulation on marriage registration introduced by China‚Äôs Ministry of Civil Affairs last week has sparked significant online discussion. One notable change is that couples will no longer need their hukou, or household register, to get married. Traditionally, this document is often held by parents, meaning that those who wish to marry had to obtain it‚Äîessentially seeking parental approval. By removing this requirement, the process is simplified, giving individuals more freedom to marry, even if their parents disagree.

However, the draft regulation is drawing criticism, primarily due to the inclusion of a 30-day cooling-off period for divorce. This cooling-off period (‚ÄúÂÜ∑ÈùôÊúü‚Äù) allows either party to withdraw their divorce application within 30 days of filing. Although introduced in a draft as early as 2018, it continues to generate debate. Many feel that while the revision appears to grant more freedom in marriage, it restricts the freedom to divorce in a timely manner. Some say this is like a ‚Äúloose entry, strict exit‚Äù (ÂÆΩËøõ‰∏•Âá∫) policy, similar to Chinese university admissions. One popular comment called it ‚Äúfake freedom.‚Äù The draft regulation is open for public feedback until September 11.

üö¥ Discussions over Cycling Boy‚Äôs Death

A tragic incident in Hebei has sparked significant online discussions. In Rongcheng County, an eleven-year-old boy who was cycling with his father in a group of cyclists fell down and was run over by a car coming from the opposite direction. A dashcam video captured the group riding in the middle of the road, leaving the oncoming vehicle with little room or time to avoid the collision. The boy succumbed to his injuries shortly after the accident.

The incident has led to broader debates about the father‚Äôs responsibility. According to road safety laws, the eleven-year-old should not have been cycling on a public road, especially not in the middle of it. The situation is further complicated by reports that people had previously warned the father about the dangers of bringing his young son on high-speed cycling trips, warnings which he allegedly ignored. Although the father initially attempted to shift the blame onto the driver for speeding, public opinion has largely condemned him for being irresponsible, with devastating consequences.

üá®üá≥ Chinese Flag Controversy

A hotel in Paris, part of a Taiwanese chain, became the center of online attention this August after it failed to include the Chinese flag in its Olympic-themed decorations. The issue was brought to light by a Chinese influencer who posted a video accusing the Evergreen Laurel Hotel (ÈïøËç£Ê°ÇÂÜ†ÈÖíÂ∫ó) of refusing to display the Chinese flag, even after the influencer offered to provide one. The incident sparked significant backlash, leading domestic travel platforms like Ctrip and Meituan to delist the hotel‚Äôs booking options, including those at its Shanghai location. The hotel eventually issued an apology, but many netizens found it too vague, as it did not directly address the flag incident, instead focusing on general dissatisfaction with their decorations. The Chinese Embassy in France has since commented on the issue, expressing support for Chinese people, both at home and abroad, in their efforts to ‚Äúremain united and uphold patriotic values.‚Äù

What‚Äôs Noteworthy

Small news with big impact

The WeChat account Zhenguan (Ë¥ûËßÇ) reported on August 16 about a tragic incident involving a 33-year-old woman from a small, impoverished village in Ningxia who died alone in her rented 30th-floor apartment in Xi‚Äôan. Her body was not discovered for a long time, and by the time it was found, it had decomposed to the point of being unrecognizable. In the article, titled ‚ÄúA Women From Out of Town Died in the Apartment I Rented Out<" ("‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§ñÂú∞Â•≥Â≠©ÔºåÊ≠ªÂú®‰∫ÜÊàëÂá∫ÁßüÁöÑÂÖ¨ÂØì"), which has since been deleted, a landlord shares their story of how they discovered the single young woman had died inside the studio apartment. The article paints a picture of a once-bright rural girl who became disillusioned as the competitive educational system and the pressures of city life crushed her spirit. The woman, who depended on her family‚Äôs financial support, hadn‚Äôt ordered or cooked any food for nearly twenty days, since she was last seen in May, suggesting she most likely starved to death in her apartment.

The article quickly went viral over the weekend. The incident, which allegedly took place during the summer, resonated with people as they began filling in the gaps of the story with their own interpretations. They felt for the woman, who had worked hard in life but had found herself unable to live up to expectations. Some saw the young woman‚Äôs story as a tragic reflection of the struggles in contemporary Chinese society. Some blamed city life, others blamed rural culture. But many also doubted the story‚Äôs authenticity.

After Chinese media outlets like Zhengzai Xinwen (Ê≠£Âú®Êñ∞Èóª) began investigating the matter, it was revealed that many details in the story were inaccurate. The incident did not occur in Xi‚Äôan but in Xianyang. People from the woman‚Äôs hometown mentioned that she was socially withdrawn and may have struggled with mental health issues, though she was never formally diagnosed. Local police confirmed that the incident is real and that it is still under investigation by a local branch of the Xianyang Public Security Bureau. Regardless of the exact circumstances, her story has struck a chord, with one popular comment on Weibo stating: ‚ÄúThere are countless others like her in society who are experiencing the same struggles. No matter what you‚Äôre going through, I hope you don‚Äôt give up on life.‚Äù

What‚Äôs Popular

The latest buzz in arts, marketing & pop culture

This summer‚Äôs Olympic fever in China has been evident across various e-commerce platforms. Whether it was the sudden popularity of Zheng Qinwen‚Äôs tennis skirt or the craze over diver Quan Hongchan‚Äôs ugly animal slippers, Chinese consumers have eagerly embraced Olympic-themed shopping.

Recognizing the influence of athletes during and after the Olympics, brands have tapped into their potential by launching various collaborations. A particularly successful example is the plush paddles endorsed by Olympic table tennis star Fan Zhendong (Ê®äÊåØ‰∏ú). The 27-year-old national table tennis player, often referred to as the ‚ÄúNational Ping Pong God‚Äù (ÂõΩ‰πíÁî∑Á•û), not only clinched double gold in Paris but also endorses several brands, including the British Jellycat brand, which created the plush paddle toys.

One popular video shows Fan playing table tennis with the plush paddle toy, which quickly sold out after his Olympic victory. The toy was restocked twice in three days before selling out again. Many commenters praised the toy for being so cute, and in light of Wang Chuqin‚Äôs now-famous broken paddle incident, others joked that it‚Äôs a good thing the plush paddles are unbreakable.

What‚Äôs Memorable

Best reads from the archive

China‚Äôs well-known political and social commentator Hu Xijin has been noticeably absent from Chinese social media for about a month. The former editor-in-chief of the Global Times has not posted on his account since July 27‚Äîan extraordinary, unannounced, and unexplained pause from his typically daily social media activity. In light of Hu‚Äôs sudden silence, we take a look back eight years into the What‚Äôs on Weibo archive, when another social media commentator, Ren Zhiqiang, abruptly went silent, and his account subsequently disappeared.

Weibo Word of the Week

The catchword to know

Fan Cultured | Our Weibo word of the week is ‚Äòfan-cultured‚Äô or ‚Äòfandom-ization‚Äô (f√†nquƒÅnhu√† È•≠ÂúàÂåñ). While f√†nquƒÅn È•≠Âúà literally means ‚Äúfan circle,‚Äù the suffix hu√† Âåñ is generally used to indicate a process of transformation or turning into something, similar to the ‚Äú-ization‚Äù suffix in English.

The term f√†nquƒÅnhu√† È•≠ÂúàÂåñ refers to the recently much-discussed phenomenon where something‚Äîoften outside the realms of entertainment‚Äîreceives passionate support from people who begin to form online fan circles around it, changing the dynamics in ways that resemble the relationships between celebrity idols and their fans.

A recent example of something being ‚Äúfan-cultured‚Äù or ‚Äúfandom-ized‚Äù is how fans have started to form extremely strong communities around China‚Äôs table tennis stars, defending them as if they were idols. This fan behavior has been criticized by Chinese authorities, who see it as toxic fan culture that goes against the Olympic spirit (read more).

But ‚Äúfandom-ization‚Äù goes beyond sports. There are also strong fan club dynamics surrounding Chinese pandas. Even inanimate objects can become ‚Äúfan-cultured.‚Äù For example, the Little Forklift Truck (Â∞èÂèâËΩ¶) that was part of the construction of the Huoshenshan emergency specialty field hospital during the early days of the Covid crisis. The construction process was live-streamed, and millions of viewers found the little truck‚Äîworking tirelessly around the clock‚Äîso cute and brave that it became ‚Äúfan-cultured.‚Äù

This is an on-site version of the Weibo Watch newsletter by What‚Äôs on Weibo. Missed last week‚Äôs newsletter? Find it here. If you are already subscribed to What‚Äôs on Weibo but are not yet receiving this newsletter in your inbox, please contact us directly to let us know.

During the Paris Olympics, not a day went by without table tennis making its way onto Weibo‚Äôs trending lists. The Chinese table tennis team achieved great success, winning five gold medals and one silver.

However, the women‚Äôs singles final on August 3rd, between Chinese champions Chen Meng (ÈôàÊ¢¶) and Sun Yingsha (Â≠ôÈ¢ñËéé), took viewers by surprise due to the unsettling atmosphere. The crowd overwhelmingly supported Sun Yingsha, with little applause for Chen Meng, and some hurled insults at her. Even the coaching staff had stern expressions after Chen‚Äôs win.

This bizarre scene sparked heated discussions on Chinese social media, exposing the broader audience to the chaotic and sometimes absurd dynamics within China‚Äôs table tennis fandom.

‚ÄúI welcome fans but reject fandom culture.‚Äù

When Sun Yingsha and Chen Meng faced off in the women‚Äôs singles final, the medal was destined for ‚ÄòTeam China‚Äô regardless of the outcome; the match should have been a celebration of Chinese table tennis.

However, the match held significant importance for both Sun and Chen individually. Chen Meng, the defending champion from the previous Olympics, was on the verge of making history by retaining her title. Meanwhile, Sun Yingsha, an emerging star who had already claimed singles titles at the World Cup and World Championships, was aiming to complete a career Grand Slam (World Championships, World Cup, and Olympics).

Sun Yingsha has clearly become a public favorite. On Weibo, the table tennis star ranked among the most beloved athletes in popularity lists.

This favoritism among Chinese table tennis fans was evident at the venue. According to reports from a Chinese audience member, anyone shouting ‚ÄúGo Chen Meng!‚Äù (‚ÄúÈôàÊ¢¶Âä†Ê≤π‚Äù) was quickly silenced or booed, while even cheering ‚ÄúCome on China!‚Äù (‚Äú‰∏≠ÂõΩÈòüÂä†Ê≤π‚Äù) was met with ridicule. After Chen Meng‚Äôs 4-2 victory, many in the audience expressed their frustration and chanted ‚Äúrefund‚Äù during the award ceremony. Meanwhile, social media was flooded with hateful posts cursing Chen for winning the match.

For many who were unfamiliar with the off-court drama, the influence of fandom culture on the Olympics was shocking. However, in the world of Chinese table tennis, such extreme fan behavior has been brewing for some time. Even during the eras of Ma Long (È©¨Èæô) and Zhang Jike (Âº†ÁªßÁßë), there were already fans who would turn against each other and others.

This year‚Äôs men‚Äôs singles champion, Fan Zhendong (Ê®äÊåØ‰∏ú), had long noticed the growing influence of fandom culture. ‚ÄúWhat has happened to Chinese table tennis fans over the years?‚Äù

On Weibo, a blogger (@3Âè∑ÂéÖÊ£ÄÁ•®ÂëòÂ∑•) posed a question that struck a chord with many, garnering over 30,000 likes: ‚ÄúWhat has happened to Chinese table tennis fans over the years?‚Äù

In the comments, many blamed Liu Guoliang (ÂàòÂõΩÊ¢Å) for fueling the fan culture around table tennis. Liu, the first Chinese male player to achieve the Grand Slam, retired in 2002 and then became a coach for the Chinese table tennis team. His coaching career has been highly successful, leading players like Ma Long and Xu Xin (ËÆ∏Êòï) to numerous championships.

Beyond coaching, Liu has been dedicated to commercializing table tennis. Under Liu‚Äôs leadership, the commercialization of the Chinese table tennis team began after the Rio Olympics, where China won all four gold medals. ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you say you want to crack down on fan culture?‚Äù

In response to the controversy surrounding the Chen vs. Sun match, the Beijing Daily published an article titled ‚ÄúHow Can We Allow Fandom Violence to Disturb the World of Table Tennis?‚Äù The article addressed the growing problem of ‚Äúfandom culture‚Äù infiltrating table tennis, a trend that originated in the entertainment world. It highlighted how extreme fan behavior, including online abuse and disruptive actions during matches, harms both the sport and the mental well-being of athletes. While fan enthusiasm is important, the article stressed that it must remain within rational limits.

This article foreshadowed actions taken shortly after. On August 7th, China‚Äôs Ministry of Public Security announced an online crackdown on chaotic sports-related fan circles.
